Political competition among populares and optimates allowed ideological variation though often destabilizing.
Successful generals and wealthy elites translated military and economic success into durable political power.

Paterfamilias authority and private household governance were central features of Roman society.

Scientific activity was practical and decentralized focused on engineering and military needs.
Education emphasized rhetoric and civic virtue but lacked centralized ideological control.
